title: 1 Kings Chapter 12 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Kings chapter 12 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Kings Chapter 12 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Kings Chapter 12.

questions.question: Where did Rehoboam go to be made king?
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:1 states that Rehoboam went to Shechem because all Israel had come there to make him king.

questions.question: Who was in Egypt when Israel called for him to come and speak to Rehoboam?
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:2-3 mention Jeroboam, son of Nebat, was in Egypt and was called by Israel to speak to Rehoboam.

questions.question: What did the people ask Rehoboam to do regarding the yoke of his father?
questions.correctAnswer: Make the yoke lighter
questions.explanation: In 1 Kings 12:4, the people requested Rehoboam to lighten the heavy yoke that his father had put upon them.

questions.question: How long did Rehoboam ask the people to wait before he gave them an answer?
questions.correctAnswer: Three days
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:5 records that Rehoboam told the people to depart for three days and then return for his answer.

questions.question: Who did Rehoboam first consult for advice on how to answer the people?
options: The old men who served Solomon
The young men who grew up with him
questions.correctAnswer: The old men who served Solomon
questions.explanation: According to 1 Kings 12:6-7, Rehoboam consulted the old men who stood before his father Solomon for advice.

questions.question: True or False: Rehoboam followed the advice of the old men and spoke kindly to the people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:8-14 shows that Rehoboam rejected the old men's counsel and followed the young men's advice to speak harshly to the people.

questions.question: What metaphor did Rehoboam use to describe how he would be stronger than his father?
options: My little finger shall be thicker than my father's loins
My hand is mightier than my father's sword
My crown is heavier than my father's
My throne is higher than my father's
questions.correctAnswer: My little finger shall be thicker than my father's loins
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:10 records the young men's advice that Rehoboam say his little finger would be thicker than his father's loins.

questions.question: What was the people's response when Rehoboam refused to lighten their yoke?
options: They said, 'What portion have we in David?' and went to their tents
They asked for more time to think
questions.correctAnswer: They said, 'What portion have we in David?' and went to their tents
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:16 reports that the people asked what portion they had in David and returned to their tents, rejecting Rehoboam's rule.

questions.question: Who did Rehoboam send over the tribute that was stoned to death by Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Adoram
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:18 states that Rehoboam sent Adoram over the tribute, and Israel stoned him to death.

questions.question: True or False: After the kingdom split, Jeroboam was made king over all Israel except the tribe of Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:20 says Jeroboam was made king over all Israel, and only the tribe of Judah followed the house of David.

questions.question: How many chosen men did Rehoboam gather from Judah and Benjamin to fight Israel?
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:21 records that Rehoboam assembled 180,000 chosen warriors from Judah and Benjamin.

questions.question: Who delivered God's word to Rehoboam, commanding him not to fight Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Shemaiah the man of God
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:22-23 shows that Shemaiah received God's word to tell Rehoboam and others not to fight their brethren.

questions.question: True or False: Rehoboam and his army ignored God's command and went to war against Israel.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:24 states they hearkened to the word of the LORD and returned to their houses instead of fighting.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeroboam built ______ in mount Ephraim and dwelt therein.
questions.correctAnswer: Shechem
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:25 explains that Jeroboam built Shechem in mount Ephraim and dwelt there.

questions.question: What did Jeroboam make to prevent the people from going to Jerusalem to worship?
questions.correctAnswer: Two calves of gold
questions.explanation: 1 Kings 12:28-29 tells that Jeroboam made two golden calves and set them in Bethel and Dan.

medium.title: 1 Kings Chapter 12 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Kings Chapter 12 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 1 Kings 12 teach us about humility and seeking wise counsel when facing leadership challenges?
options: Rehoboam listened only to the young men and ignored the elders
Rehoboam sought counsel from both old and young men but chose to follow the advice of the younger men
Rehoboam immediately obeyed the people's request without advice
Rehoboam rejected all advice and made a decision on his own
questions.correctAnswer: Rehoboam sought counsel from both old and young men but chose to follow the advice of the younger men
questions.explanation: Rehoboam consulted with the old men and the young men, but chose to follow the advice of the young men instead of the elders, showing a failure in humility and wise leadership (1 Kings 12:6-10, 13).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with pride in leadership. Based on Rehoboam’s example, what biblical truth would you share about humility and obedience?
options: Prideful decisions can lead to division and hardship
Ignoring advice is always the best course
Showing strength means being harsh with people
Adding to burdens is a sign of good leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Prideful decisions can lead to division and hardship
questions.explanation: Rehoboam’s pride led him to reject wise counsel and add to the people's burdens, which caused division in Israel (1 Kings 12:14-16, 19). Humility and obedience to God’s guidance are essential for unity and peace.

questions.question: What does 1 Kings 12 teach about the consequences of forsaking God's direction in leadership decisions?
options: It can cause division and rebellion among God's people
questions.correctAnswer: It can cause division and rebellion among God's people
questions.explanation: Because Rehoboam did not heed the Lord’s will, the kingdom was divided and Israel rebelled against the house of David (1 Kings 12:15-19, 20). Obedience to God’s word promotes unity and peace.

questions.question: How can the example of Rehoboam’s harsh response to the people guide Christians in practicing gentleness and patience?
options: Gentleness fosters trust and loyalty, while harshness breeds rebellion
Harshness is the best way to show authority
Demanding more from others always leads to respect
Patience is a weakness in leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Gentleness fosters trust and loyalty, while harshness breeds rebellion
questions.explanation: Rehoboam’s harsh words caused the people to rebel, showing that gentleness and patience in leadership help maintain relationships and unity (1 Kings 12:14-16).

questions.question: Based on 1 Kings 12, what spiritual principle is demonstrated when God sends a prophet to prevent Rehoboam from fighting his brethren?
options: God desires peace and reconciliation among His people
God supports violence to regain control
questions.correctAnswer: God desires peace and reconciliation among His people
questions.explanation: The LORD sent Shemaiah to instruct Rehoboam and the people not to fight against their brethren because the division was from God’s plan, emphasizing peace and God’s sovereignty (1 Kings 12:22-24).

questions.question: What lesson about faith and trusting God's plan can be drawn from Israel's response to the king's rough answer?
options: When leaders reject God's guidance, people may follow God’s plan instead
People always remain loyal regardless of leadership
Faith is unrelated to leadership decisions
God punishes people for questioning leaders
questions.correctAnswer: When leaders reject God's guidance, people may follow God’s plan instead
questions.explanation: Israel rejected Rehoboam’s leadership and chose Jeroboam as king, fulfilling God’s purpose through Ahijah’s prophecy (1 Kings 12:15-20), showing the importance of trusting God's plan over human authority.

questions.question: True or False: Rehoboam listened to the wise counsel of the elders and made the yoke lighter for the people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Rehoboam rejected the elders' advice and chose to increase the burden on the people, as advised by the young men (1 Kings 12:7-14).

questions.question: True or False: Jeroboam set up golden calves to prevent the people from returning to Rehoboam's kingdom, showing a failure to trust God’s plan fully.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Jeroboam feared losing his kingdom if the people went to Jerusalem to worship, so he made two golden calves for them to worship, which became a sin (1 Kings 12:26-30).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their faith out of fear like Jeroboam. What does 1 Kings 12 teach about trusting God rather than taking sinful shortcuts?
options: Trusting God is essential, as Jeroboam’s compromise led to sin
God supports self-made plans over His commands
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting God is essential, as Jeroboam’s compromise led to sin
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s creation of golden calves was a sinful attempt to secure his reign, showing that fear should not lead to disobedience, but faith in God's plan is required (1 Kings 12:26-31, 33).

questions.question: How does Rehoboam’s failure to heed God’s word illustrate the importance of spiritual discipline and obedience in leadership?
options: Disobedience leads to division and loss of God’s favor
Spiritual discipline is optional for leaders
Leaders should rely only on their own wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience leads to division and loss of God’s favor
questions.explanation: Rehoboam’s refusal to listen to God’s prophet led to the kingdom’s division and rebellion, highlighting the necessity of obedience and spiritual discipline in leadership (1 Kings 12:15-19, 22-24).

questions.question: What practical Christian principle about humility and leadership can be learned from the people’s response to Rehoboam’s harshness?
options: Leaders should serve others with humility to maintain their trust
Leaders should assert power harshly to gain respect
People must always obey even harsh leaders
Leadership is about making people suffer
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should serve others with humility to maintain their trust
questions.explanation: The elders advised Rehoboam to serve the people humbly so they would serve him forever, but his harshness caused rebellion (1 Kings 12:7-16).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jeroboam set up two calves of gold and placed one in ______ and the other in Dan.
questions.correctAnswer: Bethel
questions.explanation: Jeroboam made two golden calves and placed one in Bethel and the other in Dan to prevent the people from going to Jerusalem (1 Kings 12:28-29).

questions.question: What does the story of Rehoboam assembling warriors from Judah and Benjamin but then heeding God's word to not fight show about submission to God's will?
options: Even in conflict, believers must obey God’s commands and seek peace
Believers should always fight for what they want
God supports warfare to regain control
Submission to God is optional in battle
questions.correctAnswer: Even in conflict, believers must obey God’s commands and seek peace
questions.explanation: Rehoboam gathered an army to fight but obeyed God’s prophet Shemaiah who told him not to fight his brethren, illustrating submission to God’s will even in difficult times (1 Kings 12:21-24).

questions.question: How does Jeroboam's creation of a feast in the eighth month demonstrate the dangers of altering God’s ordinances for personal gain?
options: It shows how inventing religious practices can lead to sin
It is an example of faithful worship
questions.correctAnswer: It shows how inventing religious practices can lead to sin
questions.explanation: Jeroboam ordained a feast in the eighth month, different from God's appointed festivals, to solidify his control, which became a sinful act (1 Kings 12:32-33).

questions.question: From 1 Kings 12, what can be learned about the importance of integrity and honesty when dealing with others, especially in leadership?
options: Integrity fosters trust and unity, while harshness and deception cause division
Dishonesty is necessary to maintain power
Leaders should use fear to control people
Deception is acceptable if it benefits the leader
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity fosters trust and unity, while harshness and deception cause division
questions.explanation: Rehoboam’s harshness and Jeroboam’s idolatry both caused division and sin, showing the importance of integrity and honest leadership (1 Kings 12:14-16, 28-31).

hard.title: 1 Kings Chapter 12 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Kings Chapter 12.

questions.question: What was the initial request of the people of Israel to Rehoboam when they came to Shechem?
options: Make the grievous service of your father lighter
Increase the taxes on the people
questions.correctAnswer: Make the grievous service of your father lighter
questions.explanation: The people requested Rehoboam to lighten the heavy yoke that his father Solomon had put upon them, as stated in 1 Kings 12:4.

questions.question: Who did Rehoboam consult first about how to respond to the people’s request?
options: The old men who stood before Solomon
The young men who grew up with him
questions.correctAnswer: The old men who stood before Solomon
questions.explanation: Rehoboam first sought advice from the old men who served Solomon, asking them how he should answer the people, as recorded in 1 Kings 12:6.

questions.question: What advice did the old men give Rehoboam regarding his response to the people?
options: Speak good words and serve the people to gain their lasting loyalty
Increase the yoke and discipline to assert authority
questions.correctAnswer: Speak good words and serve the people to gain their lasting loyalty
questions.explanation: The old men advised Rehoboam to be a servant to the people and speak kindly to them so they would serve him forever (1 Kings 12:7).

questions.question: What was the counsel of the young men that Rehoboam chose to follow?
options: Increase the yoke and discipline more harshly than Solomon
Grant the people their request and lighten the burden
Call a national assembly to decide
questions.correctAnswer: Increase the yoke and discipline more harshly than Solomon
questions.explanation: The young men advised Rehoboam to say he would make their yoke heavier and chastise them with scorpions, which he later did (1 Kings 12:10-11).

questions.question: What was the outcome when Rehoboam followed the counsel of the young men and answered the people harshly?
options: The northern tribes of Israel rebelled and departed
The people accepted his rule without complaint
The priests declared Rehoboam king over all Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The northern tribes of Israel rebelled and departed
questions.explanation: When Rehoboam rejected the people's request and increased their burden, the northern tribes said they had no inheritance in David and departed (1 Kings 12:16).

questions.question: What was the significance of the people's statement, 'What portion have we in David? neither have we inheritance in the son of Jesse'?
options: It indicated a formal rejection of the Davidic dynasty
It was a call for Jeroboam to be crowned king in Judah
It was a prophetic declaration of God's promise
questions.correctAnswer: It indicated a formal rejection of the Davidic dynasty
questions.explanation: The statement symbolized Israel's rejection of Rehoboam and the house of David as their rulers, marking the division of the kingdom (1 Kings 12:16).

questions.question: Which tribe remained loyal to Rehoboam after the division of the kingdom?
questions.correctAnswer: Judah
questions.explanation: Only the tribe of Judah remained loyal to Rehoboam as king after the northern tribes rebelled (1 Kings 12:20).

questions.question: Who was over the tribute that Rehoboam sent and was stoned to death by the Israelites?
questions.correctAnswer: Adoram
questions.explanation: Rehoboam sent Adoram, who was over the tribute, and the Israelites stoned him to death (1 Kings 12:18).

questions.question: What was the divine reason behind Rehoboam's harsh response to the people, according to the text?
options: To fulfill the LORD’s prophecy through Ahijah the Shilonite
Because Rehoboam was influenced by the young men
To punish the people for their disobedience
To maintain the unity of the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: To fulfill the LORD’s prophecy through Ahijah the Shilonite
questions.explanation: The text explains that the cause of Rehoboam's refusal was from the LORD to fulfill the prophecy spoken by Ahijah to Jeroboam (1 Kings 12:15).

questions.question: Which prophet gave a message from God to Rehoboam and the house of Judah not to fight against Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: Shemaiah
questions.explanation: God's word came to Shemaiah, who instructed Rehoboam and Judah not to fight their brethren Israel (1 Kings 12:22-24).

questions.question: What action did Jeroboam take to prevent the people of Israel from returning to Rehoboam’s rule?
options: He made two golden calves as alternative worship centers
He built a large army to attack Judah
He sent ambassadors to Egypt for support
He destroyed the temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: He made two golden calves as alternative worship centers
questions.explanation: Jeroboam made two golden calves and set them up in Bethel and Dan to prevent the people from going to Jerusalem to worship (1 Kings 12:28-29).

questions.question: Where did Jeroboam place the two golden calves he made?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethel and Dan
questions.explanation: Jeroboam set one golden calf in Bethel and the other in Dan as alternative places of worship (1 Kings 12:29).

questions.question: What was the religious status of the priests Jeroboam appointed to serve at the high places?
options: They were from the lowest of the people, not Levites
They were Levites appointed by the king
questions.correctAnswer: They were from the lowest of the people, not Levites
questions.explanation: Jeroboam made priests of the lowest of the people, who were not of the sons of Levi (1 Kings 12:31).

questions.question: Jeroboam ordained a feast in the eighth month on the fifteenth day. What was unique about this feast?
options: It was a feast he devised of his own heart, like the feast in Judah but at Bethel
It was the Passover feast celebrated in Jerusalem
It was a fasting day for national repentance
It was the Feast of Tabernacles celebrated in Dan
questions.correctAnswer: It was a feast he devised of his own heart, like the feast in Judah but at Bethel
questions.explanation: Jeroboam created his own feast similar to Judah’s and celebrated it on the fifteenth day of the eighth month at Bethel (1 Kings 12:32-33).

questions.question: True or False: Rehoboam heeded the counsel of the old men and lightened the yoke on the people.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Rehoboam rejected the advice of the old men and instead followed the counsel of the young men, increasing the yoke on the people (1 Kings 12:13-14).

questions.question: True or False: The division of the kingdom was a fulfillment of a prophecy previously given by Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The chapter states that the division was from the LORD to fulfill the saying by Ahijah the Shilonite to Jeroboam (1 Kings 12:15).

theological.title: 1 Kings Chapter 12 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Kings Chapter 12 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial request of the Israelites to Rehoboam when he became king?
options: Make the yoke lighter than Solomon's
questions.correctAnswer: Make the yoke lighter than Solomon's
questions.explanation: The people asked Rehoboam to lighten the heavy yoke that Solomon had put upon them, as stated in 1 Kings 12:4. This reflects their burden under Solomon's reign. Similar appeals for mercy and lighter burdens are found in Exodus 1:11-14 where the Israelites were oppressed, and in Matthew 11:28-30 where Jesus invites the weary to find rest.

questions.question: Whose counsel did Rehoboam reject when deciding how to respond to the people?
questions.correctAnswer: The old men’s counsel
questions.explanation: Rehoboam rejected the wise counsel of the old men who advised him to be a servant to the people and speak good words (1 Kings 12:8). This rejection led to harsh leadership. The failure to heed wise counsel is a recurring biblical theme (Proverbs 1:7, Proverbs 19:20) and contrasts with Christ who perfectly obeyed the Father’s will (Hebrews 5:8).

questions.question: What was the advice given by the young men to Rehoboam regarding his response to Israel?
options: To increase the harshness and add to their yoke
To grant their request and lighten the yoke
questions.correctAnswer: To increase the harshness and add to their yoke
questions.explanation: The young men advised Rehoboam to speak harshly, saying his little finger would be thicker than his father's loins and he would chastise with scorpions instead of whips (1 Kings 12:10-11). This reflects human pride and hardness of heart, opposing God’s call to humility (James 4:6, Proverbs 16:18).

questions.question: What was the outcome when Rehoboam followed the advice of the young men?
options: The people rebelled and the kingdom split
The people accepted his rule peacefully
Jeroboam was exiled again to Egypt
Rehoboam was crowned king of all Israel
questions.correctAnswer: The people rebelled and the kingdom split
questions.explanation: After Rehoboam's harsh response, all Israel rejected him, saying, 'What portion have we in David?' and the kingdom was divided (1 Kings 12:16, 19). This division fulfilled God’s judgment and highlights human sinfulness and the consequences of pride (Romans 3:23, Judges 21:25).

questions.question: Who was made king over all Israel after the kingdom divided?
questions.correctAnswer: Jeroboam
questions.explanation: The people of Israel made Jeroboam king over all Israel except Judah (1 Kings 12:20). This illustrates God's providential sovereignty in raising leaders and the unfolding of His redemptive plan despite human rebellion (Acts 17:26, Romans 13:1).

questions.question: What was God’s instruction to Rehoboam and the tribes of Judah and Benjamin regarding fighting Israel?
options: Do not fight your brethren, return to your houses
Attack Israel to reclaim the kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Do not fight your brethren, return to your houses
questions.explanation: God, through the prophet Shemaiah, commanded Rehoboam and his army not to fight Israel but to return home, showing God's sovereign control over divisions and conflicts (1 Kings 12:22-24). This reflects God's desire for peace among His people and foreshadows the peace brought by Christ (Matthew 5:9, Romans 12:18).

questions.question: Why did Jeroboam set up two golden calves for Israel to worship?
options: To prevent the people from returning to Jerusalem to worship
To honor the LORD in new locations
Because he wanted to follow Solomon’s example
To unite Israel and Judah in worship
questions.correctAnswer: To prevent the people from returning to Jerusalem to worship
questions.explanation: Jeroboam feared that if the people went to Jerusalem to sacrifice, their hearts would return to Rehoboam, so he made two golden calves to redirect worship and secure his reign (1 Kings 12:26-28). This act became a sin, showing the dangers of idolatry and false worship (Exodus 32, Hosea 8:5-6).

questions.question: Where did Jeroboam place the two golden calves?
questions.correctAnswer: Bethel and Dan
questions.explanation: Jeroboam set one calf in Bethel and the other in Dan as centers for idol worship (1 Kings 12:29). This highlights the departure from true worship and the creation of syncretistic religious practices condemned throughout Scripture (Deuteronomy 12:29-32, Isaiah 44:9-20).

questions.question: What was sinful about Jeroboam’s appointment of priests?
options: He made priests from the lowest of the people, not from the Levites
He did not train the priests properly
He only appointed priests from Judah
He forbade priests from offering sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: He made priests from the lowest of the people, not from the Levites
questions.explanation: Jeroboam appointed non-Levitical priests, violating God's ordinance that priests come from Levi (1 Kings 12:31). This showed disregard for God's established order and contributed to Israel’s spiritual decline (Numbers 3:10, Malachi 2:7).

questions.question: What feast did Jeroboam institute in Israel?
options: A feast on the fifteenth day of the eighth month
The Passover feast in the first month
The Feast of Tabernacles in the seventh month
The Day of Atonement in the tenth month
questions.correctAnswer: A feast on the fifteenth day of the eighth month
questions.explanation: Jeroboam established a feast on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, imitating but not following the true feasts of the LORD (1 Kings 12:32-33). This reflects human innovation in worship apart from God's instructions, akin to false worship condemned in Jeremiah 7:21-23.

questions.question: What was the stated purpose of Jeroboam’s new worship system?
options: To keep the people from returning to Jerusalem and to secure his kingship
To honor the LORD with new rituals
To unite Israel and Judah in religious harmony
To fulfill the prophecy given to Solomon
questions.correctAnswer: To keep the people from returning to Jerusalem and to secure his kingship
questions.explanation: Jeroboam’s motivation was political—to prevent the hearts of the people from returning to Rehoboam by redirecting worship to local shrines (1 Kings 12:26-27). This illustrates the danger of mixing politics with religion and creating idolatry (2 Chronicles 11:15; Colossians 2:8).

questions.question: How did the LORD use Rehoboam’s refusal to heed the people’s request?
options: To fulfill His prophecy through Ahijah the Shilonite
To bless Rehoboam with greater power
To unite all Israel under Rehoboam
To bring Jeroboam back to Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: To fulfill His prophecy through Ahijah the Shilonite
questions.explanation: God allowed Rehoboam’s harshness to fulfill the prophecy spoken by Ahijah regarding Jeroboam’s rise (1 Kings 12:15). This demonstrates God’s sovereignty in using human sin to accomplish divine purposes (Isaiah 10:5-7, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What happened to Adoram, who was over the tribute under Rehoboam?
options: He was stoned to death by Israel
He was made king of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: He was stoned to death by Israel
questions.explanation: Adoram was stoned to death by the Israelites when sent to collect tribute (1 Kings 12:18). This violent rejection of Rehoboam's rule reflects the depth of the people's rebellion and the consequences of unjust leadership (Ecclesiastes 5:8-9, Proverbs 29:2).

questions.question: What tribes remained loyal to Rehoboam after the kingdom split?
questions.correctAnswer: Judah and Benjamin
questions.explanation: After the division, only Judah and Benjamin remained loyal to Rehoboam (1 Kings 12:21). This reflects the tribal divisions and God's covenantal faithfulness to David’s line, ultimately fulfilled in Christ, the descendant of Judah (Genesis 49:10, Luke 3:33).

questions.question: What does the division of Israel under Rehoboam illustrate about human leadership and divine sovereignty?
options: Human pride and sin can cause division, but God’s purposes prevail
Human leaders always perfectly obey God’s will
Divisions are always caused by foreign enemies
God abandons His people when they disobey
questions.correctAnswer: Human pride and sin can cause division, but God’s purposes prevail
questions.explanation: The division was caused by Rehoboam’s pride and rejection of wise counsel, yet God used it to fulfill His prophetic word (1 Kings 12:15, 24). Scripture consistently teaches that while human sin causes brokenness, God’s sovereign plan is never thwarted (Genesis 50:20, Isaiah 46:9-11, Romans 8:28).
